com.intel.icecp.core

Interface Attribute<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - attributes are of a type that can be sent as a message; beware of using nested generic types here as this type must be fully serializable for network transport
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    WriteableAttribute<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ArchitectureAttribute, BaseAttribute, ComplexConfigurationAttribute, FormatAttribute, IdAttribute, ModuleStateAttribute, NameAttribute, NodeUptimeAttribute, OperatingSystemAttribute, ProcessorLoadAttribute, SignAttribute, StorageUsageAttribute, SymmetricEncryptionAttribute, WriteableBaseAttribute

    public interface Attribute<T>
    Describes a Describable thing using a key-value pair; the key is a unique string (i.e. unique to that thing) and the value is of the generic type passed to the instance (and discoverable using type()). These attributes may be serialized and published over Channels; additionally, we may provide a way for setting attributes across the network

    In the future, we may add a method for retrieving the semantic model that this attribute belongs to (TODO). Currently the type() exposes the value type but using a semantic model could replace this with a string.

    Note that the value type exposed by this attribute may (and probably will) be serialized for transport over the network. Please pay special attention to common serialization gotchas like field accesibility, default constructors, public static inner classes, anonymous classes--using these mechanisms for the value type (see MyValue below) may result in errors. Simple, primitive types are encouraged (e.g. Integer, String, Map)

    An attribute implementation would look like: 

    
      class MyAttribute implements Attribute<MyValue>{
          public MyAttribute(){
              // note the presence of a default constructor
          }

          public MyValue value(){
              MyValue value = someCalculation();
              return value;
          }
      }

      String name() 
      Class<T> type() 
      T value()
      Note that returning a reference to an object held inside the attribute implementation means that external users can modify inside the implementation; to avoid this, attribute implementations should return new instances of the returned value, e.g.

    • Method Detail

      • name

        String name()
        Returns:
        the name of the attribute

      • type

        Class<T> type()
        Returns:
        the Class of the value type held in this attribute

      • value

        T value()
        Note that returning a reference to an object held inside the attribute implementation means that external users can modify inside the implementation; to avoid this, attribute implementations should return new instances of the returned value, e.g. return new String(value). Alternatively, implementations can implement a form of cloning in order to protect the original reference. Most applications, however, will likely return the (new) result of some calculation and this should not be an issue.
        Returns:
        the value of the attribute at the current time
